Cell.Data: Interact to generate a new dungeon
Your very own Personal Chest. Here you can hoard to your heart's content.\nWell, at least until you have filled it brimful.

The caves along the Coast of Wrecks were carved out by the Sea of Torment, its monstrous tide having eroded the rockface over thousands of years. Countless vessels have shattered against the shore, and Sea Svriir sift among the wreckage, looking for baubles and trinkets to take back to their nests.

The Svriirhave made short work of colonizing the country surrounding Stormfall. As a desperate final bid for survival, the city guard has retreated to the city and established fortifications, hoping it is enough to save their homes. Along the coastal highlands, the bodies of refugees litter the trails leading to the city.

Stormfall, otherwise known as the Jewel of the Sea, is a coastal city state renowned for its shipbuilding, cartographical archives, and bustling Diamond trade. It has remained a sovereign state, despite the Republic’s advances, thanks to its alliance with the Jewelled Concordat and the natural barrier offered by the Salt Deserts of Morkaï.

The merchant road is the main trade route used by caravans to reach Stormfall, leading out from the farmlands to a crossroads where it splits. The roads lead to the Republic, the city state of Vulkain, and Greyharbour far to the north. During this time of crisis, the roads are empty. None dare travel the roads for fear of slaughter.

The caves beneath the farmlands were dug by the Svriir as a means of reaching the surface. Several lairs have been connected to form an enormous supercluster. The presence of nests and beta females is indicative of two things: first, that the Svriir are here to stay; and second, that something is driving them from the depths.
A hoard of baubles, trinkets, and bodies is amassed in the Svriir’s tribute chamber. Anything perceived to have value, from ornate forks to radiant diamonds.

The soul surges have weakened the structural integrity of the tunnel network. Svriir flee to the surface or defend their eggs from the tormented souls rising from the depths. Either way, their actions leave the Alpha’s lair relatively undefended.

Since the soul surges began, surviving on the Coast of Wrecks has become an increasingly perilous affair. It was difficult before, with just the waves and the weather to contend with, but the tormented souls are an unprecedented threat to the Flayers living here. Their outpost may not survive the crisis.

This is the Brotherhood of Dawn encampment targeted by the Republic during Operation Dawnbane. The Republic used the cover of darkness to sneak along the shore and flank the Brotherhood soldiers, setting fire to their encampment. The Brothers were unable to rally before being slaughtered.

The Green Bluffs has a microclimate that makes it the driest region in Stormfall’s territory. The climate and the tree cover made the forest an ideal hiding spot for the Flayers. When the opportunity presented itself, they spilled from the bluffs to raid the farmlands.

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">The smuggler’s path is an ancient network of caves that leads down to sea level. It has been the site of cat and mouse encounters between guards and smugglers for hundreds of years. That was before the Sea Svriir began to emerge from the sea.</Font>

The halls of a forgotten civilization, fallen into ruin long before Stormfall was conceived. It has remained undisturbed for centuries, but with the arrival of the Sleeper’s procession, the dead have risen to roam their ruined city.

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">There is nothing but death in this place. A suffocating darkness engulfs the halls, emanating a paralysing cold. The bones of the builders form mounds of human suffering, rising high above the darkness. </Font>

In the dark corners of the Necropolis, sculptures and tablets lie hidden with stories etched into stone. Terrifying beasts of light and shadow oppress human figures, the builders of this city that would become their grave. The beasts have since disappeared, but a new oppressor, the Sleeper, has come to terrorize the city’s resting spirits.

The builders of the Necropolis kept digging until they excavated a pristine, golden, gate, barring the way to an ancient structure. Around the gate, the scattered bodies of the excavators suggest this was their last discovery before they became the bones decorating the halls of the Necropolis.

At the centre of Anankis a catalyst hums. The most extraordinary feats of Creation would have been impossible without these catalysts; the Primordials wielded their power to perform their greatest deeds. It may be this power that the Sleeper seeks.

The Primordial Guardians protect Anankis, ever diligent despite the disappearance of their Primordial masters. They are all that remain of Anankis’ history, and without them, all knowledge regarding the catalysts and their function will be lost. Now, the Cult of the Sleeper threatens to erase them.

Primordial catalysts were designed to channel faith to the centre of the superstructure that connects them. The Cult of the Sleeper have twisted its purpose, siphoning fear from the surface to fuel the catalyst and their nefarious ambitions.

The soul magic that pervades the Necropolis is the Cult of the Sleeper's work. The procession passed through here on their way to the Halls of Anankis, where their ultimate objective lay. The shards of ice are the residue left behind by their magic.

The catalyst in Anankis emanates a radiant aura of Primordial energy. The power of Creation. All humans have come from this source, and all of them hold a slice of its power in their hearts. This connection draws them to these auras, giving rise to settlements that thrive in their glow.

The Anankis catalyst has exceeded its power threshold, causing the soul surges around Stormfall. The surges create a feedback loop; the fear they generate is absorbed by the catalyst, fuelling its power until it reaches another threshold. Unless this loop can be interrupted, Stormfall will fall. The Cult of the Sleeper protects Anankis’ core, determined despite the loss of Yudaï.

“Merchants around the world go to great lengths avoiding the Sea of Torment. But if they find themselves needing a crew to sail it, we’re the ones they turn to. We know its treacherous waters better than anyone.”

Sataë, 12th Captain of Stormfall’s Merchant Fleet

“I lost my mother in the crowd that amassed before the city gates. I saw her pushed into a stream of panicked refugees forcing their way into the city. When I reached the gates, the guards were ordered to close them in front of us. Now we have resigned ourselves to our fate: death in the crossfire.”

Ebira, Stormfall Refugee

“Closing the gates on my people was by far the hardest decision I have ever made. We allowed as many as we could behind the walls, but now the lower rings are packed with refugees… we will soon have famine and disease to contend with. Letting any more of them inside would tear apart the city. ”

Merchant-Prince Damaskus of Stormfall, Keeper of the Sea Jewel

“The Merchant-Prince has rented out our war fleet and none of us know where to. He must be receiving a lot of coin for their services, but without them we are ill-equipped to fight the Svriir at our gates! Conscripts are not enough; we need real soldiers!”

Sandor, Thunderblade of Stormfall

“When Svriir eggs hatch, the Svriirlings that emerge are physiologically identical. Only once the hive has assigned them their role do they mutate into something more useful. Simply put, they are the most adaptable creatures I have ever studied. I would not be surprised if we started to see more variants soon.”

Achemid, Advisor of Merchant-Prince Damaskus on the Svriir crisis

“Omega males are cowardly creatures; you’ll rarely find them leading the charge. They hunt in groups for baubles and trinkets to give as tribute to the hive’s beta females. If a tribute is accepted, the females will spit some sort of mucus onto their chosen omega. The dominating theory is that it contains mutagens, causing further mutations amongst the omegas so that they become unique beta males, rising in the hierarchy of Svriir society.”

Achemid, Advisor of Merchant-Prince Damaskus on the Svriirs crisis

“The Svriir are highly intelligent, social creatures; far more than the mindless beasts we perceive them to be. They have hierarchies, practice modesty, and have established norms regarding courtship. Perhaps by studying this behaviour, we could find a way to undermine their expansion efforts.”

Achemid, Advisor of Merchant-Prince Damaskus on the Svriir crisis

“The Flayers used the chaos of the Svriir crisis to raid the farmlands. Now they’re the ones being raided by these souls. I’m enjoying the irony. Maybe some of those souls are the innocents they slaughtered, taking their revenge. Who knows?”

Edric, Veteran Purifier of the Republic

“Crimson Keep has been lost to the occult corruption of the Brotherhood of Dawn.

We shall not be tarnished.
We shall not stand down.

An army of Purifiers is to be sent North to retake what is ours.
All known locations of the Brotherhood of Dawn are to be attacked in retaliation and purified at once.”

Edict 3.3.3.4.6. from the United Republic of Mankind’s Senate

“It used to be a place for romantic ballads and weddings. But with recent events, I start to realize: should we survive, there won’t be any celebration for my people, only grief and sorrow.”

Merchant-Prince Damaskus of Stormfall, Keeper of the Sea Jewel

“Thunderblade Odao asked the Merchant-Prince to blow up the caves below Stormfall. He wanted to destroy the black market undermining our economy. I had to step in to explain that doing so would cause the entire city to collapse on itself. He hasn't spoken to me since.”

Lord Arkan, Engineering Counsellor in Merchant-Prince Damaskus’s court

“We tracked the Cult of the Sleeper’s procession to the Necropolis. Apparently, they were already aware of its existence and location. I’m concerned that this means they are led by a supernatural being, from another time. May the Searing Song protect us all.”

Calahad, Aurora Knight of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“There are Necropoles buried all across the four realms. They share an identical iconography, and all have been found to preserve human bones on a similar scale to each other. One wonders what series of events led to such a mass extermination of human life.”

Xil’Sarei, famous historian

“We humans forget our history. We forget the rise and fall of past civilizations, and doom ourselves to make the same mistakes. We drown in our petty squabbles when there is so much more at stake. But don’t fret. The Sleeper is here to guide us, to turn our gaze to the glorious shared future that awaits us all.”

Vhegguad, Seal of Anankis

“The power of Anankis slumbers, all but forgotten. But the Sleeper remembers. He knew of its location and shared it with me. I will bend this catalyst to our cause – harness its power to fuel his ambitions.”

Yudaï, Whisper of Anameterassü

“The earthquakes and soul surges are spreading. We were barely coping with the Svriir, and now this… Our citizens are losing hope. They talk about their options: they can leave and be torn apart by Flayers and souls, or stay here, and wait for the Svriir to breach the city walls. Either way, all that awaits them is death.”

Faärad, Thunderblade of Stormfall

“The dissident Primordials betrayed Creation, but they were outmatched by their loyalist kin. During their banishment to the Abyss they became Abbathus, discovering that fear generated more faith from their followers than other emotions. They reaped this faith, its twisted source reflecting their own twisted ambitions.”

Mizzeonth, Primordial Guardian of Anankis

“A new era awaits. One without Primordials. It will be an era of peace, free of the trivial conflicts that have always plagued Creation. The Covenant of the Blind will provide.”

Yudaï, Whisper of Anameterassü

“It is my divine duty to fight. As long as I am able, I shall be a shackle on the Abbathus’ greed. I will be the guiding hand, leading humanity to its survival.”

Mizzeonth, Primordial Guardian

“Humans dream of the day their benevolent creators return. I cannot fathom why. If their Primordial benefactors were so benevolent, then this structure would hardly gorge itself on their fear now, would it?”

Yudaï, Whisper of Anameterassü

“The faith reaped by fear is unparalleled. Once you have felt its power, nothing else can match it. Stormfall will quake with fear, and we will be sure to feed upon it.”

Yudaï, Whisper of Anameterassü

Totems and corpses litter the Jackals of Dusk’s stronghold, where human offerings are used to empower the darkest shadow magic. Roars and screams are heard echoing in the distance from Mercy’s barbaric arena, where hopefuls fight to the death for a chance at wealth and glory.

This once-quaint township, famed for its woodworking, now stands as a base of operations for a nefarious cult of necromancers. The Galathä River no longer flows and the land lies damp, punctuated with the debris of a decaying army.

As a mysterious mist envelops the lower rings of Stormfall, citizens and refugees alike are fearful and desperate. But the gates to the upper ring remain closed. Nobles secure their wealth as unrest threatens to turn into chaos.

The Vault of Hope’s inner sanctum houses a piece of the Helion, a legendary weapon that summons the power of Anathëa, Lady of Dawn. Adorned with other religious iconography, this chamber has hosted the most important ceremonies conducted by the Brotherhood of Dawn.

The Jackals of Dusk settled here after being exiled from C’tul. Verdant and green, the settlement is situated over a river. Rudimentary houses are poised on stilts, built into the canopy of the forest. Slave cages litter the area, mostly empty after lucrative dealings with the Cult of the Sleeper.

A makeshift Brotherhood camp outside the devastated Vault of Hope. Here, survivors of the Cult of the Sleeper’s ambush regain their strength. Hierophants are healing injured knights while those still standing clear the remaining undead from the area.

This Primordial structure that once sustained the Primordials now feeds the Covenant of the Blind and their Abbathus lords. As they grow in power, hope slips further and further away from humanity’s grasp.

On the fringes of flesh’s domain, the corruption creeps through the ancient forest on the outskirts of Cordanon. Blades of grass grow veins and trees fester with boils, converting the land into a corpulent, red hellscape.

The fleshy foliage is thick here, the organic corruption almost fully complete; pools of tainted water, fruit that bleeds to the touch. A once-busy thoroughfare that connects Cordanon to the rest of the continent now lies unused, covered in a layer of dust.

Where it all started, the original summoning circle that brought Lambach into the mortal plane, now a chasm of pulsating sinew. While expanding their empire of corrupted flesh, Lambach changed forms multiple times, each iteration more gruesome and deadly than the last.

A near-silent city, corrupted by flesh and inhabited by a single lifeform, the Lambach. Veins run down the buildings, weeds are blood red, denizens of the flesh file through the streets to push the frontier of corruption.

A remarkable temple, the Vault of Hope was built by the Brotherhood of Dawn to house a piece of the Helion. Now it is plagued with an army of the dead, its sacraments defiled by the unsavoury magic of the Cult of the Sleeper.

Fleshy creatures pour from the walls, created from the recycled flesh of Cordanon’s people. Failed experiments lie here, festering and decomposing. The walls pulsate and groan like machinery, manufacturing an unending flood of twisted monsters.

Failed clones of Valeria line the walls of this underground chamber. An oozing, putrid workshop, the smell of forged flesh dominates the atmosphere; fresh tests spawn out of the walls and collapse in pain on the meaty floor.

This cavern remains relatively unaffected by the corruption of flesh, providing temporary refuge from the Lambach. Creatures untainted by flesh’s corruption seek refuge here, but their assimilation is inevitable.

A twisted laboratory, here the Lambach builds its latest fetid creations. The walls are littered with failures, hybrid animals that never took a second breath, deformed abominations and clones of “interesting specimens.”
An undead horde has swept through this land, ambushing the Brotherhood of Dawn in the process. Now, reanimated bodies of the holy warriors wander this blood-soaked earth alongside their assailants.

“A slave for every victory! Who’s next to face my champions? Strike true, or you’ll beg for mercy from Mer– oh, who cares? Just start fighting already.”

Mercy, Dark Paragon of the Jackals of Dusk

“I think of myself as a benefactor: humans are cattle, herded by tyrants and put to work until the day they die. By gifting them with undeath, I free them of their mortal obligations.”

Nerukaï, Demon of Souls

“One must feel for the peasants as they flock desperately to our homes in the upper ring. However, to let them enter would doom the entire city. It is better for us to survive than no-one at all.”

Salomë Vengd of House Streamrunner

“If you understood what the Helion was, you would not be so flippant about your guard duties. That spear once summoned the Lady of Dawn Herself! It cannot fall into the wrong hands.”

Gernese, Eos of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“It was childishly simple for me to borrow the power of Shadow: one must only sacrifice a worshipper to the lost Primordial Moros. In this world full of traitors and heretics, there’s no lack of suitable subjects.”

Janaris, Emissary of the Sleeper

“The Vault of Hope has fallen, but the message it carried lives within us: there is a future for the Brotherhood. We must make camp and rest if we hope to meet that future at full strength.”

Gernese, Eos of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“Cooperation is a virtue; we should know. Every individual that joins us finds a purpose. And soon, they will find Him too: Ashtaroth. With Him, we will merge into our full body. With Him, we will have our full mind.”

The Lambach

“Of course they rushed into danger. They had the Helion on their side. Why fear the woods? Poor fools. What if some part of them’s still alive, somewhere inside that abomination?”

Ilan, Aurora Knight

“When I got off my horse, I saw her hooves were covered in blood. I searched the soil: no body. It was the earth that was bleeding. Cordanon is my biggest market, but I’m not going back there for any price.”

Olyffe Theobor, Travelling Merchant

“We treasure the mortal idea of self-improvement. Our own form will improve until it becomes unstoppable. We will be Ashtaroth’s ultimate champion.”

The Lambach

“There was a kind of illness going ’round. Bulging veins, reddish eyes, swelling necks. The sick’d leave their beds at night and vanish into the fields for hours. Glad I got out while I could.”

Robin, migrant from Cordanon

“We were not only the guardians of humanity, but the watch people of Our Lady. We keep Her tenets intact within our Vaults. In thanks, She blesses our rituals and shares Her power.”

Lucinda, Hierophant of the Searing Song

“The Cult of the Aberrant is known to treat human flesh as a raw material. Worshippers undergo extensive body modifications, or even donate their bodies to build new creations. During the disaster of Fellerton, they harvested unconsenting individuals for the very first time, and have continued since.”

Xil’Sarei, famous historian

“We must not overlook this one. Oh, the things we could do with her. Her fierce disposition, her unbreakable will; she will enrich us, and we will enrich her.”

The Lambach

“There was an earthquake. The ground cracked. Then, it happened. Canopies of meat stretched over the streets. Our own neighbours were cutting us down and feeding us to that thing. I hid until the screams stopped. Oh, don’t look at me like that. What else could I have done?”

Carmine, refugee from Cordanon

“We intend to create a world of perfect beings. That does not mean we demand conformity. When one integrates unique and improbable humans to the greater whole, the reaction can be most fascinating.”

The Lambach

“My tribe was swayed by the call of demon tamers and corpse stalkers. They forgot the old ways: honouring the spirits, communing with the dusk, consecrating slain beasts as was done in C’tul. I will restore these traditions.”

Zima, She Who Ferries The Lost

Far gone is the Jewel of the Sea’s splendour. The filtered lanterns that lit the streets are now replaced by ghostly orbs of light in the fog. They murmur, insinuate, spark paranoia in those who will listen. The noble circles are frozen over with the same terror as every other borough.

When the Kingdom of Alia fell, becoming the United Republic of Mankind, the Brotherhood of Dawn fled Republican persecution. They were forced into an underground existence both literal and figurative. Networks of subterranean havens sprouted all over Wolcen, including below the Vault of Truth.

The Brotherhood of Dawn built this temple to contain the Helion. The alarm system releases clots of yellow smoke, delivering a singular message: the Vault of Truth has been breached. The Covenant of the Blind is here.

The Dawngate doesn’t open for just anyone. In the wing dedicated to light, devotees of Anathëa must find clarity and purpose. Before they’re able to wield the dawn in battle, they must fully comprehend its power through meditation and ritual.

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">Until a few weeks ago, the faithful came to this wing to find conviction in the darkest of days. Now, the halls lie deserted, theology books hastily abandoned by the Brotherhood Hierophants. Steel hearted men once walked here, now wandering as thralls of Fury.</Font>

The Southern Red Wastes crawl with the bones of foolhardy explorers, insectoid monsters, and a stubborn Svriir population. But anyone fighting through the beasts can look up and glimpse the frozen plains of the north, and recall that a far more lifeless terrain lies close by.

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">The Republic’s usual strategy is to divide the battlefield into a grid, coldly assigning forces from cell to cell. Today, because of the two-pronged attack of the Purifiers and the Instigators, that strategy falters like it has never done before.</Font>

A bloody waltz has consolidated at the heart of the battle. The Purifier forces dance back as the Instigators pacify their men, and stop at the end of a supply line from Republic territory. The Senate feeds the fight with wrought steel and Federator cannons, which maintain a steady fire on the keep.

The smell of blood and sulphur imbues every grain of sand. The Purifiers who don’t fall in line with the forces of Fury are torn through with cauterized wounds. Pacified units approach their unsuspecting fellows, and spread the curse of the Blind Prince.

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">Most would consider Crimson Keep’s location a nightmare; arid, hostile, and distant from any trading posts. But the Keep never was concerned with the outside world. It pulls inwards by some inexplicable gravity, containing something which defies containment.</Font>

<Font Size="18" Color="#FFFFFF">As Fury’s Ascent drives relentlessly onward, the elevator mechanism in the Eastern Tower groans. The metal expands with the heat of rising magma. As temperatures climb, it becomes inevitable: one day the chains will melt away, and when they do, Crimson Keep will be lost completely.</Font>

Crimson Keep’s generators are powered with geothermal energy. Sharp rises in seismic activity have made the plant increasingly volatile. A recent eruption of hot magma eroded the structure’s integrity, and as engineers struggled to make increasingly unrealistic repairs, they arrived: Fury.

The Republic never intended to build Crimson Keep. In the desert, they encountered the Monolith, a strange construct which seemed to emanate the power of Fury. First, they attempted to destroy it, testing all manner of conventional weapons. When all failed, they chose to quarantine the artefact.

The lock mechanism barring the Monolith prevents anything from coming out. The Republicans neglected anything that might come in. The Brotherhood of Dawn entered, attempting to study the facility, just as Fury demons began pouring into Crimson Keep. This fateful coincidence would define the conflict at hand.

This bridge is the only way in or out of the Monolith’s enclave. Access is highly restricted. Only a few Republican scholars come in, seeking ways to destroy the artefact. Little progress has been made, but one discovery haunts their research: the structure had lain for aeons under the sand, waiting to be found.

Pristine concentric vistas dominate the interior of the Monolith. All this combination of movement serves an arcane purpose: processing and focusing the power of faith. A soundless wave beats at the inner ear while the wheels turn: the Abyss knocking at the fabric of the world.

A conflux of energy rages at the summit of the Monolith, and every step closer brings a sense of dread. Something akin to thunderclaps resounds from the structure’s heights, snuffing out all sound for a moment. Apparitions shift right below the skin of the guests in faint iridescent light.

Three beams scorch a path through the earth, finding their origin in Cordanon, Gehenna, and Stormfall. They converge here; the energy and fear of thousands, fed to the Monolith. Its appetite is nearly satisfied, and the world waits.

“I can’t explain these seizures. A few of my patients have demonstrated such symptoms before; eyes rolling back, a pale sheen over their face, convulsing muscles. But there’s something different. A single word can’t do it justice: a single spark of electricity from their skin to mine, a whisper that seems to disappear before I can truly hear it. Am I touched with some dark spirit? Should I stay away from my own children when they need me most dearly?”

Artemy Beckraft, Physician

“Take these bindings off me! Pacified or not, we need to go back for the others. We swore an oath, didn’t we? Brothers and Sisters, till the sun bleaches our bones!”

Imogen, Initiate of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“I offer peace to the Dawn worshippers, and they respond by sealing the door to their Inner Sanctum. Come now, if their Lady shines so bright, my presence won’t obscure Her.”

Sinadrahel, Herald of the Blind Prince

“Our fallen warriors sleep within that hall. To think of their tombs being desecrated by our own men is intolerable. We must act fast to preserve our Brothers’ legacy.”

Gernese, Eos of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“A Brother of Dawn’s education is erudite. We do not place a sword in the hand of any tempestuous child. First, we quiet the whirlwind within their hearts, so they might see a way forward without bloodshed. Before they wield our spears, they must sing our songs.”

Lucinda, Hierophant of the Searing Song

“Archion has an entire economy founded on guides to the Northern Red Wastes. They claim us, the Departed Rangers, as their sources. Rubbish. Three of us left for that frontier. I was the only one to make it halfway. If I couldn’t make it, no one did.”

Djohariah, Ranger of The Departed

“Retreat now? While the demons sleepwalk on the battlefield? I’d rather hand my resignation to the Inquisitor in person. Victory is at hand. Keep at them!”

Talrog, Justicar of the Purifier Army

“I have gone through our inventory, I have placed every order we could possibly need, but none of this will help if we don’t have the forces to defend our camp. We’re fighting on two fronts, and no weaponry is going to change that. If we don’t get reinforcements by tomorrow, this fight is over.”

Gerta Hollis, Logistics Officer in the Purifier Army

“Keep your bandages. You might be one of them. I’d rather bleed out here than let them take me. Leave me to die! And if you are who you seem… then tell Ithra I’m sorry.”

Nameless Soldier of the Purifier Army

“Events like those at Crimson Keep may teach us a lesson: that our greatest weakness lies in the evils we must tolerate. The diseases we quarantine, rather than exterminate, are those that will infect us in the end.

Johan Bereich, Senator of the United Republic of Mankind

“The mechanism can’t take much more of this heat. The more it expands, the harder it will be to operate the elevator. Should it fail, the keep will be cut off from reinforcements, and if that happens… well, if that happens then there will be no hope for us at all…”

Argon Valkner, Republican Engineer

“How did we miss this? Where were the signs? Now magma rains on the Keep, destroying everything we’ve worked so tirelessly to build. But we cannot stop. If the plant’s generators fail, the Keep will fall apart. That cannot happen. The stakes are too great. We must keep going, work harder. There is nothing else.”

Argon Valkner, Republican Engineer

“The Senate is unsatisfied with the Purifiers’ progress. If Grand Inquisitor Otranto is unable to destroy the Monolith, then the Senate will assign a new expert. We will dispatch our demonologists to the Red Wastes to begin plans for containment. We shall make no concessions to heresy.”

Edict 3.3.3.6.7. from the United Republic of Mankind’s Senate

“The Crimson Keep was built with a spine, veins, and nerves. The electrified traction system is a living core, meant to hold unspeakable evil inside.”

Argon Valkner, Republican Engineer

“We were hoping to study the Monolith and finish what the Purifiers had started. All the evidence indicated that this was a structure far more ancient than even the Helion fragments. We might have clarified all this, were it not for the Republic’s pride.”

Calahad, Aurora Knight of the Brotherhood of Dawn

“Make no mistake. We may protect the Primordial structures, but we also protect you from them.”

Anasareth, Primordial Guardian

“Question the Primordials however much you like, but you have reaped the bulk of their gifts. We Guardians sacrifice our lives to thankless service, but never doubt for even a moment.”

Anasareth, Primordial Guardian

“For a time, I believed Anathëa abandoned us. Now, I realize it does not matter. She could not help us if She wanted to. If the Daybreakers wish to prove me wrong, let them try. That is a battle I hope to lose.”

Heimlock, Grand Inquisitor of the Purifiers
